'''Parental alienation''' is the process, and the result, of [[psychological manipulation]] of a child into showing unwarranted fear, disrespect or hostility towards a parent and/or other family members.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":0">{{cite book|last1=Warshak|first1=Richard A.|title=Divorce Poison|date=2009|publisher=Harper Collins|isbn=978-0061984235|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QRkMjqXrmsIC|accessdate=1 October 2017}}</ref> It is a distinctive form of psychological abuse, towards both the child and the rejected family members, that occurs almost exclusively in association with family separation or divorce, particularly where legal action is involved.<ref>{{Cite book|title = The High-Conflict Custody Battle: Protect Yourself and Your Kids from a Toxic Divorce, False Accusations, and Parental Alienation|last = Baker|first = AJL|publisher = New Harbinger|year = 2014|isbn = 9781626250734|location = Oakland, USA|pages = }}</ref> It undermines core principles of both the [[Universal Declaration of Human Rights]] and the United Nations [[Convention on the Rights of the Child]]. Most commonly, the primary cause is a parent wishing to exclude another parent from the life of their child, but other family members or friends, as well as professionals involved with the family (including psychologists, lawyers and judges), may contribute significantly to the process.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://aaml.org/sites/default/files/MAT107_7.pdf|title = Parental Alienation: Overview, Management, Intervention, and Practice Tips.|last = Warshak|first = R.A.|date = 2015|journal = Journal of the American Academy of Matrimonial Lawyers|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 1 October 2017}}</ref> It often leads to the long-term, or even permanent, [[Family estrangement|estrangement]] of a child from one parent and other family members<ref>{{Cite book|title = Adult Children of Parental Alienation: Breaking the Ties that Bind|last = Baker|first = Amy, J.L.|publisher = W.W. Norton & Co.|year = 2007|isbn = 978-0393705195|location = |pages = }}</ref> and, as a particularly [[Adverse Childhood Experiences Study|adverse childhood experience]], results in significantly increased lifetime risks of both mental and physical illness.<ref name="bernetw"/>
== Overview == First described in 1976 as "pathological alignment", parental alienation refers to a situation in which a child unreasonably rejects a non-custodial parent.<ref name = Bow2009>{{cite journal | last = Bow | first = JN |author2=Gould JW |author3=Flens JR | year = 2009 | title = Examining Parental Alienation in Child Custody Cases: A Survey of Mental Health and Legal Professionals | journal = The American Journal of Family Therapy | volume = 37 | issue = 2 | pages = 127–145 | doi = 10.1080/01926180801960658|url=http://www.drjamesrflens.com/_Bow_et_al.__2009___Examing_parental_alienation_in_child_custody_case.pdf }}</ref> [[Richard A. Gardner]] proposed [[parental alienation syndrome]] in the 1980s based on his clinical experience with the children of divorcing parents. Parental alienation lacks a single definition and its existence, cause and characteristics have been the subject of debate. Gardner's concept of a syndrome has failed to gain acceptance. Some [[empirical research]] has been performed, though the quality of the studies vary widely and research in the area is still developing.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Hands | first1 = A. J. | last2 = Warshak | first2 = R. A. | year = 2011 | title = Parental Alienation Among College Students | url = | journal = The American Journal of Family Therapy | volume = 39 | issue = 5| pages = 431–443 | doi=10.1080/01926187.2011.575336}}</ref>
A survey of literature suggests that alienating behaviors by both parents are common in high-conflict divorces.<ref name = Bow2009/> Rejected parents tend to lose a sense of warmth and empathy with the child. As a result, the rejected parent may become passive, depressed, anxious, and withdrawn – characteristics that may encourage further rejection. The parent that the child aligns with (the aligned parent) may engage in alienating behaviors, including undermining the other parent. These behaviors may be conscious and deliberate or may reflect a lack of awareness on the effect of the actions on the children. Direct alienating behaviors occur when one parent actively undermines the other parent, such as making derogatory remarks about the other parent, telling the child that the other parent is responsible for the separation, or telling the child that the other parent is the cause of financial difficulties. Indirect alienation behaviors occur when one parent fails to support access or contact with the other parent or tacitly accepts the child's negative behaviour and comments towards the other parent.<ref name = Bow2009/><ref name = Bala2007/>
=== Causes === The causes of alienation can be divided into two broad categories, *Realistic estrangement, in which a parent's harmful or abusive behaviors or substance abuse result in the alienation of the child;<ref name=acorn/> and *Pathological alienation, in which the alienation results from pathological aspects of the child's family relationships, and is not a rational response to the behavior of the alienated parent. Realistic estrangement is a different phenomenon from "pathological alienation". The former is an understandable refusal by a child to see an [[child abuse|abusive]] parent, while the latter is emotionally harmful and unjustified.<ref name = Bala2007/>
=== Symptoms === Symptoms associated with parental alienation include: *The child engages in a pattern of "denigration" against a targeted parent for unjustified reasons and uses "frivolous rationalizations" that are "disproportionate" to the circumstances.<ref name=inq/> *The child may display a "complete lack of ambivalence" wherein the rejected parent is viewed as "all bad" and the favored parent is viewed as "all good."<ref name=echo/> This lack of ambivalence is associated with "[[Splitting (psychology)|splitting]]."<ref name="newsweek2014">{{cite journal|title=Bernet et al. (2017). An Objective Measure of Splitting in Parental Alienation: The Parental Acceptance-Rejection Questionnaire. Journal of Forensic Sciences. doi: 10.1111/1556-4029.13625|journal=Journal of Forensic Sciences|volume=63|issue=3|pages=776–783|last1=Bernet|first1=William|last2 = Gregory|first2=Nilgun|last3=Reay|first3=Kathleen M.|last4=Rohner|first4=Ronald P.|doi=10.1111/1556-4029.13625|pmid=28833110|year = 2018}}</ref> Splitting refers to a primitive division of the ego into "all good" and "all bad" objects to prevent the "generalization of anxiety."<ref>{{Cite book|title=Kernberg, O. F. (1995). Borderline Conditions and Pathological Narcissism.|last=|first=|publisher=Jason Aronson, Inc.|year=1995|isbn=9780876681770|edition= Reissue|location=Princeton, NJ|pages=|language=English}}</ref> *The child may display "reflexive support" for the parent they favor during disagreements between the rejected parent and the favored parent.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://psychlaw.net/criteria-for-the-diagnosis-of-parental-alienation/|title=Lorandos, D. (2016). "Criteria for the Diagnosis of Parental Alienation." PsychLaw.net|last=|first=|date=|website=www.psychlaw.net|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=19 August 2018}}</ref> *The child may use "borrowed scenarios" that involve making "identical" statements to those of the "alienating parent" when the alienating parent makes disparaging comments against the rejected parent.<ref name=":1" /> *The child may display an "independent thinker phenomenon" which involves comments by the child that their decision to reject the targeted parent was arrived at without any influence from the alienating parent.<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Baker, J. L. & Darnall, D. C. (2007). A Construct Study of the Eight Symptoms of Severe Parental Alienation Syndrome. Journal of Divorce & Remarriage, 47(1-2).|journal=Journal of Divorce & Remarriage|volume=47|pages=55–75|doi=10.1300/J087v47n01_04|year = 2007|last1 = Baker|first1 = Amy J. L.|last2=Damall|first2=Douglas C.}}</ref> *The child may display an "absence of guilt" regarding their denigration of the targeted parent.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fact.on.ca/Info/pas/gard02c.htm|title=Gardner, R. A. (2002). The Empowerment of Children in the Development of Parental Alienation Syndrome. The American Journal of Forensic Psychology, 20(2), 5-29.|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=19 August 2018}}</ref> *The child's vilification of the targeted parent spreads to "extended family" members.<ref name=":2" />
==Theories== Some researchers emphasized the role of an alienating parent, termed variously the "programming" parent or "embittered-chaotic parent",<ref name = Bow2009/> while other researchers have focused on the "alienated child", and the relationship dynamics that contribute to the alienation.<ref name="Bala2007">{{cite journal |last = Bala|first = N|author2 = Fidler B|author3 = Goldberg D|author4 = Houston C|year = 2007|journal = Queens Law Journal|volume = 33|title = Alienated Children and Parental Separation: Legal Responses from Canada's Family Courts|pages = 79–138|url = http://heinonline.org/HOL/LandingPage?collection=journals&handle=hein.journals/queen33&div=7&id=&page=}}</ref><ref name=Jaffe2002>{{cite book |last=Jaffe |first=PG |author2=Lemon NKD |author3=Poisson SE |title=Child Custody & Domestic Violence |publisher=[[SAGE Publications]] |year=2002 |pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=bbZmp7ALOq4C&pg=PA52 52–54] |isbn=978-0-7619-1826-4}}</ref>
Within the context of relationship dynamics, alienation is seen as a breakdown of [[attachment (psychology)|attachment]] between parent and child that may be caused by a variety factors. These researchers have proposed a more complex analysis, in which all family members may play a role in the alienation. This "systems-based" view acknowledges that a child may be alienated from one parent with no alienation programming from the other parent.<ref name = Bow2009/><ref name = Bala2007/> The behaviors of all family members, including those of the alienated parent, may lead to [[family dysfunction]] and the rejection of a parent.<ref name= Ackerman2001>{{cite book |author=Ackerman MJ |title=Clinician's guide to child custody evaluations |publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons|Wiley]] |location=New York |year=2001 |pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=q9E_rg94Cs4C&pg=PA73 73–82] |isbn=978-0-471-39260-6}}</ref><ref name=Waldron1996>{{cite journal |last=Waldron |first=KH |author2=Joanis DE |url= http://fact.on.ca/Info/pas/waldron.htm |title=Understanding and Collaboratively Treating Parental Alienation Syndrome |journal=American Journal of Family Law |volume=10 |pages= 121–133 |year=1996}}</ref> Under this approach, when a child is estranged from a parent it is necessary to evaluate all contributing factors and all possible remedies to the estrangement.<ref name=Bala2007/><ref name=Sparta2006>{{cite book |last=Sparta |first=SN |author2=Koocher GP |title=Forensic Mental Health Assessment of Children and Adolescents |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |year=2006 |pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=6bmBtQ2Zl-IC&pg=PA83 83], [https://books.google.com/books?id=6bmBtQ2Zl-IC&pg=PA219 219–221] |isbn=978-0-19-514584-7}}</ref>
===Motivation=== In one conception of parental alienation, driven by a specific parent, a parent who experienced feelings of inadequacy or abandonment in their childhood can have those feelings re-triggered by a divorce or breakup. In response, that parent can [[Repetition compulsion#Postmodern formulations|reenact]]<ref name=acorn/><ref name=Pingitore2015/><ref name=Pearlman2005>{{cite journal | last=Pearlman | first=Laurie| title=Clinical Applications of the Attachment Framework: Relational Treatment of Complex Trauma | journal=Journal of Traumatic Stress | volume=18 | issue= 5| year = 2005 | pages=449–459 | doi= 10.1002/jts.20052| pmid=16281242| url=http://delphicentre.com.au/uploads/Pearlman,%20L.A.,%20Courtois,%20C.%20%282005%29%20RelationalTxofCmplxtTrauma.JTS.pdf}}</ref><ref name=Levy1998>{{cite journal | last=Levy | first=Michael| title=A Helpful Way to Conceptualize and Understand Reenactments | journal = The Journal of Psychotherapy Practice and Research | volume=7 | issue=3 | year = 1998 | pages=227–235 | doi= | pmc=3330499 | pmid=9631344}}</ref><ref name=Sadock>{{cite book|author=Benjamin Sadock PhD|title=Kaplan & Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry|publisher=LWWW|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=ubG51n2NgfwC&pg=PA261&lpg=PA261&dq=trauma+reenactment+textbook&source=bl&ots=tn2C5lygwY&sig=ejbMNsLZBQcOKx03tKH1Su74ebI&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CIcBEOgBMAlqFQoTCO_K7vPjgcgCFcFxPgodWvYFkw#v=onepage&q=trauma%20reenactment%20textbook&f=false 216]|isbn=978-0781787468|year=2008}}</ref><ref name=Kolk1997>{{cite journal | last=van der Kolk | first=B.A.| title=The psychological consequences of overwhelming life experiences | journal=Psychological Trauma | volume=7 | issue=3 | year = 1987 | pages=5 | doi= | url= }}</ref><ref name=Kolk2005>{{cite journal | last=van der Kolk | first=B.A.| title=Developmental Trauma Disorder: Towards a rational diagnosis for children with complex trauma histories. | journal=Psychiatric Annals | volume=35 | issue=5 | year = 2005 | pages=401–408 | doi= | url=http://www.traumacenter.org/products/pdf_files/preprint_dev_trauma_disorder.pdf}}</ref><ref name=Reyes2008>{{cite book |last=Reyes |first=Gilbert |author2=Elhai Jon |title=The Encyclopedia of Psychological Trauma |publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons|Wiley]] |year=2000 |pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=O3rSIn_qTkAC&pg=PT1119&dq=The+Encyclopedia+of+Psychological+Trauma+reenactment&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CB0Q6AEwAGoVChMI852c5f2MyAIVw6uACh1BCAJL#v=snippet&q=Reenactment&f=false 0] |isbn=978-0470110065}}</ref><ref name=LeadershipCouncilBrain>{{cite web|last1=van der Kolk|first1=BA|title=The compulsion to repeat the trauma|url=http://www.leadershipcouncil.org/1/res/brain.html|website=The Leadership Council on Child Abuse & Interpersonal Violence : The Effect of Childhood Trauma on Brain Development |accessdate=5 December 2015}}</ref> a false narrative related to their own childhood, where the child's other parent symbolizes an inadequate or abusive parent, the child symbolizes a victim of the other parent, and the parent using harmful parenting practices symbolizes a good parent ostensibly trying to protect their child.<ref name=Fidler>{{cite book|author=Barbara Jo Fidler|title=Children Who Resist Postseparation Parental Contact: A Differential Approach for Legal and Mental Health Professionals |publisher=Oxford University Press |pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=ocUupL4YcnkC&pg=PA47&lpg=PA47&dq=%22Parental+alienation+and+the+DSM+V%22&source=bl&ots=AAdSCewGoX&sig=oZCnKkZpvL-M-J6Ckbf2p5Bp3tg&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CD8Q6AEwBWoVChMI2IzqnvGxyAIVS5qACh3_WQDE#v=onepage&q=%22the%20favored%20parent%20may%20have%20a%20personality%20disorder%20or%20mental%20illness%22&f=false 30]|isbn=978-0199895496|date=2012-09-13 }}</ref> The role of the bystander such as friends, therapists, and judges is to confirm the delusion for the parent, which was already partially confirmed for them by the child acting like a victim<ref name=acorn/><ref name=Greenfield2015/><ref name=newsweek2014/><ref name=Pearlman2005/> However, in reality, the other parent is neither inadequate nor abusive; rather, the parent using the harmful parenting practices is abusive.<ref name=acorn/><ref name=Pingitore2015/><ref name=Greenfield2015/> In effect, the parent who fears inadequacy or abandonment is able to [[Psychological projection|project]] their fears onto the other parent<ref name=acorn/> because "all can plainly see" that it is the other parent who is rejected and abandoned by the child and who is "inadequate".<ref name=echo/>
A parent who uses harmful parenting practices may suffer from [[borderline personality disorder]] or [[narcissistic personality disorder]],<ref name=inq/><ref name=acorn/><ref name=echo/><ref name=stines2015/><ref name=Greenfield2015/><ref name=Fidler/> related to an experience of feeling inadequate or abandoned while growing up. This feeling can be re-triggered by a divorce or breakup, causing them to [[Decompensation#Psychology|decompensate]] into [[persecutory delusions]].<ref name=Pingitore2015/><ref name=stines2015/><ref name=Fidler/><ref name=Millon2011>{{cite book |author=Theodore Million|title=Disorders of Personality:Introducing a DSM / ICD Spectrum from Normal to Abnormal 3rd Edition|publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons|Wiley]]|year=2011 |pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=-u5lAsunPu0C&pg=PA407&dq=millon+persecutory+delusion+decompensation+%22Under+conditions+of+unrelieved+adversity+and+failure%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCQQ6AEwAWoVChMI48v_nsrZxwIVC8uACh09uAUy#v=onepage&q=millon%20persecutory%20delusion%20decompensation%20%22Under%20conditions%20of%20unrelieved%20adversity%20and%20failure%22&f=false 407–408] |isbn=978-0470040935}}</ref><ref name=Masterson1981>{{cite book |author=James Masterson, M.D.|title=The Narcissistic and Borderline Disorders: An Integrated Developmental Approach|publisher=[[Routledge]]|year=1981 |pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=grUdWczSIoUC&pg=PA38&lpg=PA38&dq=acute+psychotic+decompensation+with+paranoid+ideation&source=bl&ots=gU5fr-nUqr&sig=3sJZQo8yyj6IcFoXP8lfhr6XvZE&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCUQ6AEwAGoVChMIuMfR4J7axwIViBweCh2nWAh-#v=onepage&q=acute%20psychotic%20decompensation%20with%20acute%20paranoid%20ideation&f=false 38] |isbn=978-0876302927}}</ref> These parents may believe that they do not need to follow social norms of fairness,<ref name=inq/><ref name=echo/> and they may "parentify their own children",<ref name=Oldham2007parentify>{{cite book|last1=Oldham|first1=John M.|last2=Skodol|first2=Andrew E.|last3=Bender|first3=Donna S.|title=The American Psychiatric Publishing Textbook of Personality Disorders|date=2007|publisher=American Psychiatric Publishing|isbn=978-1585626625|pages=364|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gxpXTm9T1MsC&pg=PA364|accessdate=1 October 2017}}</ref> "excessively bind their children to themselves",<ref name=Oldham2007parentify/> "demand absolute, unlimited control over their children while threatening rejection",<ref name=Oldham2007parentify/> project their own fears onto the other parent,<ref name=Oldham2007parentify/> abandon their spouse in favor of their children,<ref name=Oldham2007parentify/> and revive their own childhood attachment trauma after a difficult experience.<ref name=Oldham2007parentify/>
===Mechanism=== The techniques of harmful parenting may be subtle and "genuine".<ref name=inq/><ref name=acorn/><ref name=Fidler/> A parent can [[Triangulation (psychology)|triangulate]] the child into the marital conflict<ref name="irishtimes">{{cite web |last1=Gartland |first1=Fiona |title=Jail time for parental alienation not in best interests of children |url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/crime-and-law/jail-time-for-parental-alienation-not-in-best-interests-of-children-1.2350370 |website=Irish Times |accessdate=29 September 2015}}</ref> by encouraging the child to make even minor complaints about the other parent and then "enthusiastically validating" them. This signals to the child that the other parent is dangerous<ref name=echo/><ref name="BakerSurviving">{{cite web |last1=Baker |first1=Amy |title=Surviving Parental Alienation, Part 2: The parental alienation tipping point |url=https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/caught-between-parents/201410/surviving-parental-alienation-part-2|website=Psychology Today |accessdate=3 October 2015}}</ref>{{mcn|date=November 2017}} and insensitive.<ref name=echo/><ref name=BakerSurviving/> This encouragement to complain manipulates the child into the role of victim without the child's awareness,<ref name=stines2015/><ref name=BakerSurviving/> allowing the parent to move into the protector role, forcing the other parent into the "inadequate" parent role, and leaving no trace of what happened for bystanders who only see the child acting as a "victim".<ref name=echo/><ref name=Greenfield2015/><ref name=newsweek2014/> Over time, the combined effects of growing closer to the alienating parent through this complaining process<ref name=echo/> and growing further from the rejected parent as the result of focusing on negative things about the other parent cause the child to reject their other parent as being inadequate.
A parent may also mix in [[lie]]s,<ref name=echo/> partial lies,<ref name=BakerSurviving/>{{ums|date=November 2017}} and [[exaggerations]],<ref name=echo/> particularly ones that the child may not be able to verify or where only the true part of the partial lie is easy to verify.<ref name=toxicex>{{cite book|last1=Baker|first1=Amy|title=Coparenting with a Toxic Ex|date=2014|publisher=New Harbinger Publications|isbn=978-1608829583|pages=85–86}}</ref> As the result of being encouraged to act as judge of their rejected parent,<ref name=echo/> the child then feels superior to their rejected parent, leading to the symptoms of [[grandiosity]], entitlement, and haughty arrogance. This feeds the [[delusion]] of the parent, that they are protecting the child from an inadequate parent.<ref name=Greenfield2015/> The child then begins to adopt this [[delusion]] also.<ref name=acorn/><ref name=echo/><ref name=newsweek2014/>
Because the child and parent are from different generations, this qualifies as a [[Triangulation (psychology)#The Perverse Triangle|perverse triangle]],<ref name=Gottlieb2012>{{cite book|author=Linda Gottlieb|title=THE PARENTAL ALIENATION SYNDROME: A Family Therapy and Collaborative Systems Approach to Amelioration|publisher=Charles C Thomas|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=WMTwCAAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=linda+gottlieb+the+parental+alienation+syndrome&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CBwQ6AEwAGoVChMIurOG0IWOyAIVTI6SCh3zGANw#v=onepage&q=perverse%20triangle&f=false 4,87,180,214,222,249,254,258,259]|isbn=978-0398087364|year=2012}}</ref><ref name=BakerWorking>{{cite book|author=Amy J. L. Baker PhD|title=WORKING WITH ALIENATED FAMILIES A Clinical Guidebook|publisher=Routeledge|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=Rxq-Bsj18ZgC&pg=PT172&lpg=PT172&dq=#v=onepage&q=perverse%20triangle&f=false 200, 230,238]|isbn=978-0415518031|year=2013}}</ref> further complicated by [[enmeshment]],<ref name=LudmerIntervention/><ref name=Goldstein>{{cite book|author=Mark Goldstein|title=Handbook of Child Custody|publisher=Springer|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=s79OCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA185&lpg=PA185&dq=%22parental+alienation%22+enmeshed&source=bl&ots=6GzVXAjF8W&sig=2ZVRNbjnqGnCIiSKEHU2pe3sA38&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CE0Q6AEwCTgyahUKEwj9sOags6fIAhXJPB4KHWTQDMI#v=onepage&q=enmeshed&f=false 186, 194, 267]|isbn=978-3319139418}}</ref><ref name=Kruk2013Reunite>{{cite web|last1=Kruk|first1=Edward|title=Parent-Child Reunification After Alienation: Strategies to Reunite Alienated Parents and Their Children|url=https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/co-parenting-after-divorce/201305/parent-child-reunification-after-alienation|website=Psychology Today|accessdate=3 October 2015}}</ref><ref name="BakerBreakingEnmesh">{{cite book|author = Baker, A.J.L.|title = Adult Children of Parental Alienation Syndrome: Breaking the Ties That Bind|publisher = W. W. Norton & Company|pages = |isbn = 978-0393705195|year = 2007}}</ref><ref name=Cowen2014>{{cite book|author=Philip A. Cowan|title=Family, Self, and Society: Toward A New Agenda for Family Research |publisher=Routledge |pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=yGehAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA206&dq=minuchin+%22loss++of++psychological++boundaries%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CB0Q6AEwAGoVChMIstKSxZazyAIVSBc-Ch2Obg8g#v=onepage&q=minuchin%20%22loss%20%20of%20%20psychological%20%20boundaries%22&f=false 206]|isbn=978-0805809992|year=1993 }}</ref>{{mcn|date=November 2017}} and made even worse because a member of the [[Triangulation (psychology)#The Perverse Triangle|perverse triangle]] has a personality disorder,<ref name=inq/><ref name=acorn/><ref name=echo/><ref name=Greenfield2015/> climaxed by the [[Splitting (psychology)|splitting dynamic]] of the parent with the personality disorder that requires the ex-spouse to also become the ex-parent of the child.<ref name=Pingitore2015/> Finally, the child may be led to misinterpret the grief they experience from the loss of a parent as pain that means the rejected parent is abusive, since they mainly experience it in the presence of the rejected parent.<ref name=stines2015/>
===Treatment=== The success of restoring the child's [[Attachment in children|attachment]] to their parent hinges on first protecting the child from harmful parenting.<ref name=acorn/><ref name=Greenfield2015/> A study suggests that the child does not experience this protection as being traumatic.<ref name=Greenfield2015/><ref name=Kruk2015>{{cite web|last1=Kruk|first1=Edward|title=Recent Advances in Understanding Parental Alienation: Implications of Parental Alienation Research for Family-Based Intervention|url=https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/co-parenting-after-divorce/201507/recent-advances-in-understanding-parental-alienation|website=Psychology Today|accessdate=13 September 2015}}</ref>
According to one theory,<ref name=LudmerIntervention/> when symptoms of alienation are present, structured intervention is likely to be more effective than traditional counseling. Structured intervention involves: * developing critical thinking to overcome rejection and enmeshment dynamics * resetting the child's place in the family hierarchy * addressing the family system * temporarily protecting the child from the bad parenting practices of the enmeshed parent.
Advocates of structured intervention argue that traditional counseling, based on the therapeutic alliance, is susceptible to: * delays from a lack of milestones and schedules * sabotage by a parent with an interest in making it fail * exclusive focus on a child's feelings and complaints to the exclusion of addressing the family system * the ineffectiveness of a parent apologizing for fabricated, exaggerated, or distorted complaints.
=== Other approaches === Some<ref name="inq">{{cite web|url=http://www.ccthomas.com/details.cfm?P_ISBN13=9780398088811|title=Lorandos et al. (2013). PARENTAL ALIENATION: The Handbook for Mental Health and Legal Professionals. Springfield, IL: Charles C. Thomas.|last1=|first1=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=19 August 2018}}</ref><ref name=acorn>{{cite web|last1=Bertholdo|first1=Stephanie|title=PARENT ALIENATION What happens when ex-spouses wage war with children on the front line|url=https://www.toacorn.com/articles/parent-alienation/|website=Thousand Oaks Acorn|accessdate=29 August 2015|date=2013-08-15}}</ref><ref name="echo">{{cite web|url=https://www.fact.on.ca/Info/pas/gardnr85.pdf|title=Gardner, R. A. (1985). Recent Trends in Divorce and Custody Litigation. Academy Forum, 29(2), 3-7.|last1=|first1=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=19 August 2018}}</ref><ref name=Pingitore2015>{{cite web|last1=Pingitore|first1=Marco| title=Parental Alienation, Interview with Craig Childress | url=http://www.psicologiagiuridica.eu/alienazione-parentale-intervista-craig-childress/2015/10/05/ | website=Italian Society of Forensic Science|accessdate=3 October 2015}}</ref><ref name=LudmerIntervention>{{cite web|last1=Ludmer|first1=Brian|title=Structured intervention trumps therapy in child estrangement cases|url=http://www.advocatedaily.com/Structured-intervention-trumps-therapy-in-child-estrangement-cases.html|website=Advocate Daily|accessdate=2 November 2015}}</ref><ref name=stines2015>{{cite web|last1=Stines|first1=Sharie|title=Narcissism and Parental Alienation Syndrome|url=http://pro.psychcentral.com/recovery-expert/2015/11/narcissism-and-parental-alienation-syndrome|website=Psych Central|accessdate=8 November 2015|date=2015-11-02}}</ref> have discussed a different approach for severe cases that defines a set of psychological symptoms in a child and proposes a psychological explanation for how those symptoms were caused by harmful parenting practices and why a parent would employ those parenting practices.<ref name=inq/><ref name=acorn/><ref name=echo/> In this approach, the phenomenon is seen simply as a combination of psychological problems, each of which psychologists understand and recognize.<ref name=Greenfield2015>{{cite web|last1=Greenfield|first1=Beth|title=The Controversial Therapy That's Shaping Custody Battles|url=https://www.yahoo.com/parenting/the-controversial-therapy-thats-shaping-custody-128797596692.html|website=Yahoo Parenting|accessdate=13 September 2015}}</ref> According to this theoretical formulation, "the pathology traditionally called ‘parental alienation' are manifestations of well-established forms of existing pathologies.”<ref name=Pingitore2015/><ref name=Greenfield2015/>
== Professional acceptance == The history of parental alienation reflects an evolution of its acceptance by professionals involved in custody cases. A 2009 survey of mental health and legal professionals found broad skepticism of the concept of parental alienation syndrome, and caution in relation to the concept of parental alienation.<ref name = Bow2009/>
===Mental health professionals=== Mental health professionals are reluctant to recognize so-called parental alienation syndrome.<ref name = Bow2009/> In the past, the American Psychiatric Association and American Psychological Association<ref>{{cite web|title=Statement on Parental Alienation Syndrome|url=http://www.apa.org/news/press/releases/2008/01/pas-syndrome.aspx|website=American Psychological Association|accessdate=7 October 2017|date=1 January 2008}}</ref> have held a neutral view of parental alienation as a distinct syndrome.<ref>'Parental Alienation, DSM-5, and ICD-11: Response to Critics' William Bernet, MD and Amy J. L. Baker, PhD (2013)</ref>
In anticipation of the fifth version of the [[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders]], which was released in 2013, William Bernet argued for the inclusion of ''parental alienation disorder'', a diagnosis related to parental alienation. His conception makes reference to parental alienation and a variety of other descriptions of behaviors he believes represent the underlying concept of parental alienation disorder.<ref name=Bernet2008>{{cite journal | last=Bernet | first=W| title= Parental Alienation Disorder and DSM-V | journal = The American Journal of Family Therapy | volume = 36 | issue = 5 | year = 2008 | pages = 349–366 | doi = 10.1080/01926180802405513 }}</ref> Despite lobbying by proponents,<ref name="Rotstein2010">{{cite news|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/10046/1036018-114.stm|title=Mental health professionals getting update on definitions|last=Rotstein|first=Gary|date=February 15, 2010 |work=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette |accessdate=2010-03-02 }}</ref> in December 2012, the proposal was rejected.<ref>{{cite web|title=American Psychiatric Association Board of Trustees Approves DSM-5-Diagnostic manual passes major milestone before May 2013 publication|url=http://dsmfacts.org/materials/american-psychiatric-association-board-of-trustees-approves-dsm-5/|publisher=American Psychiatric Association|date=1 December 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131005021044/http://dsmfacts.org/materials/american-psychiatric-association-board-of-trustees-approves-dsm-5/|archivedate=5 October 2013|df=}}</ref>
Some argue that elements of parental alienation are covered in the [[DSM-5]] under the diagnosis: "Parent-Child Relational Problem".<ref name="bernetw">{{cite journal|last1=Bernet|first1=William|last2=Wamboldt|first2=Marianne Z.|last3=Narrow|first3=William E.|title=Child Affected by Parental Relationship Distress|journal=Journal of the American Academy of Child & Adolescent Psychiatry|date=July 2016|volume=55|issue=7|pages=571–579|url=http://www.kenniscentrum-kjp.nl/app/webroot/files/tmpwebsite/Downloadables_trauma_en_kindermishandeling_bijlagen/Bernet_et_al._-_CAPRD_-_2016-07.pdf|accessdate=7 October 2017|doi=10.1016/j.jaac.2016.04.018|pmid=27343884}}</ref> For example, the child's perception of an alienated parent "may include negative attributions of the other's intentions, hostility toward or scapegoating of the other (parent), and unwarranted feelings of estrangement".<ref>Kay, B. (2013). [http://fullcomment.nationalpost.com/2013/05/23/barbara-kay-teaching-children-to-hate-the-ex/ Barbara Kay: Teaching children to hate the ex] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130616033355/http://fullcomment.nationalpost.com/2013/05/23/barbara-kay-teaching-children-to-hate-the-ex/ |date=2013-06-16 }}. National Post, May 23, 2013.</ref><ref>Franklin, R. (2013). [https://www.nationalparentsorganization.org/recent-articles?id=20972 Limited Definition of parental alienation syndrome included in the DSM-V.] National Parent's Organization, May 26, 2013.</ref>
===Courts=== In a survey at the Association of Family and Conciliation Courts in 2010, 98% of the 300 respondents agreed with the question, "Do you think that some children are manipulated by one parent to irrationally and unjustifiably reject the other parent?".<ref name=":1">Lorandos, D., W. Bernet and S.R. Sauber (2013). Overview of Parental Alienation. In {{cite book|last1=Lorandos|first1=Demosthenes|last2=Bernet|first2=William|last3=Sauber|first3=S. Richard|title=Parental Alienation: The Handbook for Mental Health and Legal Professionals|date=2013|publisher=Charles C Thomas Publisher|isbn=978-0398087500|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mNfCCAAAQBAJ|accessdate=1 October 2017}}</ref> However, parental alienation refers not to the acts of manipulation, but rather to the child's rejection of a parent that results from alienating behavior.
Some courts recognize parental alienation as a form of child abuse with long-term effects and serious outcomes for the child. Some jurisdictions, including Brazil<ref>{{cite web|title=Brazil: Parental Alienation Criminalized|url=https://www.loc.gov/law/foreign-news/article/brazil-parental-alienation-criminalized/|website=Library of Congress|accessdate=7 October 2017|date=2 September 2010}}</ref> and Mexico, have enacted parental alienation as a criminal offense.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hill|first1=Amelia|title=Programme aims to help people affected by 'parental alienation'|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/jul/14/programme-aims-to-help-people-affected-by-parental-alienation|accessdate=7 October 2017|publisher=The Guardian|date=14 July 2016}}</ref> Other jurisdictions may suspend child support in cases where parental alienation occurs. For example, in New York, in ''Matter of Robert Coull v. Pamela Rottman'', No. 2014-01516, 2015 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 6611 (September 2, 2015), where the father was prevented from seeing his son by the child's mother through a "pattern of alienation", child support was suspended.<ref>{{ cite news | title=Father Not Obligated to Pay Child Support, Panel Finds | author=Denney, Andrew | publisher=New York Law Journal | date=9 September 2015 | url=http://www.newyorklawjournal.com/id=1202736637831/Father-Not-Obligated-to-Pay-Child-Support-Panel-Finds }}</ref> Some United States courts have also tried to address the issue through mandated reunification therapy; but no federal or state laws regulating parental alienation currently exist in the United States<ref>[http://www.wkfamilylaw.com/parental-alienation-crime/], "Should Parental Alienation Be A Crime?" - Wallin & Klarich Family Law</ref> Due to the nature of allegations of parental alienation, many courts require that a qualified expert witness testify in support of allegations of parental alienation or in association with any allegation that a parent has a mental health disorder.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Novotney|first1=Amy|title=Custody collaborations|journal=Monitor on Psychology|date=July 2008|volume=39|issue=7|page=48|url=http://www.apa.org/monitor/2008/07-08/child-custody.aspx|accessdate=7 October 2017}}</ref>
While states have broadly rejected parental alienation syndrome as a concept that may be presented in a child custody case, it remains possible to argue that parental alienation has occurred, and to demonstrate how a parent's alienating behaviors should be considered by a court when evaluating a custody case.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Larson|first1=Aaron|title=Parental Alienation in Child Custody Cases|url=https://www.expertlaw.com/library/child_custody/parental_alienation.html|website=ExpertLaw.com|accessdate=7 October 2017|date=24 February 2016}}</ref> Behaviors that result in parental alienation may reflect other mental health disorders, both on the part of the alienating parent and the alienated parent, that may be relevant to a custody determination.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kelly|first1=Joan B.|last2=Johnston|first2=Janet R.|title=The Alienated Child: A Reformulation of Parental Alienation Syndrome|journal=Family Court Review|date=July 2001|volume=39|issue=3|pages=249–266|doi=10.1111/j.174-1617.2001.tb00609.x}}</ref> The behavior of the alienated child may also be a relevant factor.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Baker|first1=Amy J.L.|last2=Eichler|first2=Amy|title=The Linkage Between Parental Alienation Behaviors and Child Alienation|journal=Journal of Divorce and Remarriage|date=2016|volume=57|issue=7|pages=475–484|doi=10.1080/10502556.2016.1220285}}</ref>

revision.text:
'''Parent-Child Interaction Therapy''' ('''PCIT''') is an intervention developed by Sheila Eyberg (1988) to treat children between ages 2 and 7 with disruptive behavior problems.<ref name="Eyberg Original">{{cite journal |doi=10.1300/J019v10n01_04 |title=Parent-Child Interaction Therapy: |journal=Child & Family Behavior Therapy |volume=10 |pages=33–46 |year=1988 |last1=Eyberg |first1=Sheila }}</ref> PCIT is an evidence-based treatment (EBT) for young children with behavioral and emotional disorders that places emphasis on improving the quality of the parent-child relationship and changing parent-child interaction patterns.<ref name="What is PCIT">{{cite web | title=What is PCIT? | website=PCIT International | url=http://www.pcit.org/what-is-pcit1.html | accessdate=18 January 2017}}</ref>
Disruptive behavior is the most common reason for referral of young children for mental health services and can vary from relatively minor infractions such as talking back to significant acts of aggression. The most commonly treated Disruptive Behavior Disorders may be classified as [[Oppositional Defiant Disorder]] (ODD) or [[Conduct Disorder]] (CD), depending on the severity of the behavior and the nature of the presenting problems. The disorders often co-occur with [[Attention-Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder]] (ADHD).<ref name="Zisser">{{cite book |last1=Zisser |first1=A.R. |last2=Eyberg |first2=S.M. |year=2010 |chapter=Parent-child interaction therapy and the treatment of disruptive behavior disorders |editor1-first=A.E. |editor1-last=Kazdin |editor2-first=J.R. |editor2-last=Weisz |title=Evidence-based psychotherapies for children and adolescents |edition=2nd |location=New York, NY |publisher=Guilford Press }}{{pn|date=April 2018}}</ref> It uses a unique combination of [[behavioral therapy]], [[play therapy]], and parent training to teach more effective discipline techniques and improve the parent–child relationship.<ref name="Hembree-Kigin">{{cite book |title=Parent–Child Interaction Therapy |last1=Hembree-Kigin |first1=T. |last2=McNeil |first2=C. |year=1995 |location=Springer, NY }}{{pn|date=April 2018}}</ref>
PCIT is typically administered once a week, with 1-hour sessions, for 10-14 sessions total and consists of two treatment phases: Child-Directed Interaction (CDI) and Parent-Directed Interaction (PDI). The CDI component focuses on improving the quality of the parent-child relationship, which will help promote changes in behavior. This sets the foundation for the PDI stage, which continues to encourage appropriate play while also focusing on a structured and consistent approach to discipline.<ref name="Eyberg Original" />
==History== PCIT was derived from several theories, including attachment theory, social learning theory, and parenting styles theory.
===Attachment theory=== According to [[attachment theory]] by Ainsworth,<ref name=”Ainsworth”>{{cite book |last1=Ainsworth |first1=M. D. S. |last2=Blehar |first2=M. C. |last3=Waters |first3=E. |last4=Wall |first4=S. N. |year=2015 |title=Patterns of attachment: A psychological study of the strange situation |publisher=Psychology Press }}{{pn|date=April 2018}}</ref> “sensitive and responsive parenting” during infancy and toddlerhood leads the child to develop an expectation that their needs can be met by the parent. Thus, parents who show their young children greater warmth and are more responsive and sensitive to their needs promote a sense of security that they can later apply to relationships with others. This can also help with more effective emotion regulation.<ref name=”Herschell”>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S1077-7229(02)80034-7 |title=Parent-child interaction therapy: New directions in research |journal=Cognitive and Behavioral Practice |volume=9 |pages=9 |year=2002 |last1=Herschell |first1=Amy D |last2=Calzada |first2=Esther J |last3=Eyberg |first3=Sheila M |last4=McNeil |first4=Cheryl B }}</ref>Children who are referred to clinics for externalizing behaviors are more likely than non-referred children to display distress when separated from the parent and to display indicators of an insecure attachment to their parent.<ref>{{cite book |first1=Mark T. |last1=Greenberg |first2=Matthew L. |last2=Speltz |chapter=Atachment and the Ontogeny of Conduct Problems |pages=177–218 |chapterurl={{Google books|rzjvCgAAQBAJ|page=177|plainurl=yes}} |editor1-first=Jay |editor1-last=Belsky |editor2-first=Teresa M. |editor2-last=Nezworski |year=2015 |title=Clinical Implications of Attachment |publisher=Routledge |isbn=978-1-317-83812-8 }}</ref>
The Child Directed Interaction (CDI) component of the PCIT applies attachment theory through its goal to “restructure the parent-child relationship and provide a secure attachment for the child”. The CDI component makes use of the idea that parents can have a dramatic effect on their child's behavior, especially during the early preschool years.<ref name="Eyberg Original" /> This is a critical period where children are more responsive to their parent's and less so to other influences such as teachers or peers.<ref name="Eyberg Original" />
===Social learning theory=== [[Social learning theory]] suggests that new behaviors can be learned by watching and imitating the behaviors of others.<ref>Bandura, A., & Walters, R. H. (1977). Social learning theory (Vol. 1). Englewood Cliffs, NJ: Prentice-hall.{{pn|date=April 2018}}</ref> Patterson (1975) further expands on this and proposes that child behavior problems are “inadvertently established or maintained by dysfunctional parent-child interactions”.<ref>Patterson, G. R. (1975). Families: Application of social learning to family life. Champaign, IL: Research Press.{{pn|date=April 2018}}</ref><ref name=”Herschell” /> There can be a “coercive interaction cycle” between parent and child where both try to control the behavior of the other. Behaviors such as arguing and aggression in children are reinforced by parent behaviors (e.g., withdrawal of demands), but negative parent behaviors can subsequently be reinforced by negative child behaviors.<ref name=”Herschell” /> In sum, children can learn many behaviors from their parents’ feedback, but this can result in negative externalizing behaviors, as well. The PDI component targets this cycle specifically by establishing consistent parenting behaviors that encourage the desired behavior in children.
===Parenting style theory=== According to [[Diana Baumrind]]’s parenting style theory (year link citation) found that the authoritative parenting style leads to the healthiest outcomes for children transitioning into adolescence.<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=6032134 |year=1967 |author1=Baumrind |first1=D |title=Child care practices anteceding three patterns of preschool behavior |journal=Genetic psychology monographs |volume=75 |issue=1 |pages=43–88 }}</ref> This style combines responsive and nurturing interactions with clear communication and firm discipline. The influence of this theory can be seen particularly in the PDI treatment phase where parents are taught to use direct commands to increase desired behavior, along with other positive and nurturing behaviors.<ref name=”Herschell” />
==Structure of the PCIT== Eyberg’s original paper (1988) thoroughly describes each assessment and treatment phase of the PCIT and includes suggestions for applying the therapy.<ref name="Eyberg Original" />
First, parents attend a training session during which the therapist explains each rule and its rationale. Each parent is also taught through one-on-one role play interactions with the therapist. Parents are also given a handout at the end of the session that summarizes the basic directions so they can review it at home.<ref name="Eyberg Original" />
After this training session, the sessions that follow will include the child. The sessions are held in a playroom, with the child playing with one parent at a time. Meanwhile, the therapist and the other parent will be observing the play through a one-way mirror or video system. The therapist can provide immediate feedback and suggestions through a “bug-in-ear” device or sit in the room to do the coaching. At the end of the session, the therapist discusses the child's progress, using summary sheets that parents can use to guide their interactions during practice sessions at home. These practice sessions serve as a “homework assignment” for parents, during which they practice the interaction with their child for five minutes a day, using homework sheets to track progress. The treatment begins with the Child-Directed Interaction phase, then is followed by the Parent-Directed Interaction (PDI) phase.<ref name="Eyberg Original" />
===Child-Directed Interaction (CDI)=== According to Eyberg (1988), the parent's goal during this stage is to follow the child's lead during play while being sure to follow the “Don’t Rules” and “Do Rules of CDI”. The child should be free to lead the activity and make their own decisions about what and how to play. By letting their children take control of the play, the parents help their child develop autonomy and independence.<ref name="Eyberg Original" />
====Don’t rules of CDI==== According to Eyberg (1988), the Don’t rules help parents step back and encourage child-led play by avoiding commands, questions, and criticisms. Commands, or instructions, would take the lead away from the child could also introduce potential disagreements into the play. Parents are also encouraged to not ask questions. This can include questions such as “How about putting the toys away?” which are actually implied commands. The concern about asking questions is that they may come off as accusatory (“Why did you choose that toy?”) or take the conversation to an “adult” level instead of letting the child play freely and naturally. The general idea is that questions provide little information, so they have limited usefulness in therapy. The third “don’t” rule is to avoid criticizing. Though criticisms can range from mild to blatant attacks on the child, criticisms in general can lead to damaging effects on the child's self-esteem. As children learn which behaviors are good or bad, they rely on what their parents say about them and believe it. Criticisms may also frustrate or anger the child and can lead to a counterattack. Taken together, criticisms are not only unproductive in therapy, but also are threats to the positive relationship that the PCIT emphasizes.<ref name="Eyberg Original" />
====Do rules of CDI==== According to Eyberg (1988), the Do rules of CDI that promote positive behavior throughout play. The first Do is to describe what the child is doing during the activity. Doing this may seem unnatural at first, but describing serves a few purposes: it allows the child to (1) lead play, (2) improve attention towards independent activities, (3) clarify the activity and encourage the child to further elaborate the play, and (4) help teach the child different concepts in a positive way. For example, the child learns through positive feedback (“you found the red one”) instead of coercion (“find the red one”).<ref name="Eyberg Original" />
The second Do is imitation. Eyberg recommends that the parents “sit close and do the same thing as the child”. The parent can add to the child's play, or do something similar, but the focus should still remain on the child's style of play. The attention that imitation can demonstrate can show the child that the parent is interested and believes what they are doing is important. Imitation may even lead to the child imitating the parent. The aim is that through the parent-child play, the child can learn cooperative play skills that they can one day use with other children.<ref name="Eyberg Original" />
Parents are encouraged to reflect what the child says during play, the third Do of CDI. This helps parents practice listening to their child. For example, when the child says “The car is fast,” the parent might say “Yes, the car is fast”. These reflections show that the parent understands and accepts what the child is saying. Additionally, using reflective statements can improve the child's vocabulary and grammar by providing clarity to the child's thoughts. It also gives the child an opportunity to agree or disagree with the parent's understanding and elaborate if needed.<ref name="Eyberg Original" />
Praise is the fourth Do, and is very important because it can make children feel good and increase warmth, an important goal of the CDI. Praise statements such as “Good job!” show the child that their creations and actions are important. This is important because children tend to believe the things parents say to them, whether they be positive or negative. The manual specifies two types of praise. “Labeled praise” statements specify exactly what the parent likes about their behavior. For example, saying “You did a beautiful job of drawing that picture” not only teaches children that they did something the parent liked, but also teaches them what they did to earn that praise.<ref name="Eyberg Original" />Because PCIT can be used from ages 2 through 7, coaching takes into account the developmental differences at each age and teaches parents to be mindful of those differences. Parents are encouraged to praise and reflect all attempts of their child to verbally communicate, as speech skills are concurrently developing.<ref name=”Herschell” />
===Parent-Directed Interaction (PDI)=== According to Eyberg (1988), during the PDI component, parents continue the skills learned in the CDI, but this time they are taught new skills to lead the play. These skills include giving verbal directions and applying the appropriate consequences to the child in a fair manner that the child can understand clearly. These steps are practiced at the clinic, and parents are not encouraged to practice at home until they feel confident.<ref name="Eyberg Original" />
Eyberg (1988) states that he first step is to give clear, direct commands for the desired behavior from the child and to avoid indirect commands, which can be too vague and confusing to the child. For example, “Put this red table in the house” is a direct command. However, an indirect command such as “Will you color the leaves green?” can be interpreted by the child as a genuine question. Another example of an indirect command is “Let’s clean up the toys”, which does not indicate clearly if both the parent and child will be doing the task or how much of the task the child will do themselves. Additionally, phrases that are too general, such as “Be good”, should be avoided, as it does not provide enough information about what exactly is expected of the child. In sum, clear statements should be used towards the child so they can understand easily without getting confused.<ref name="Eyberg Original" />
Eyberg (1988) provides some guidelines for parents to teach parents when giving direct commands. First, the commands should be stated positively and should tell the child what to do, rather than what not to do. For example, “Put your hands in your lap” should be used instead of “Stop grabbing the toys”. Secondly, the command should be one that is age-appropriate for the child. For example, telling a 2-year-old “Tie your shoe” would be considered not age-appropriate. Lastly, the command should require only one behavior at a time. This way, children need not remember long strings of orders in a single command.<ref name="Eyberg Original" />
The second step of PDI involves labeled praise when the child displays the desired behavior. For example, “I like it when you do what I tell you to do so quickly!” tells the child what specific action pleased the parent and this praise will help increase that desired behavior.<ref name="Eyberg Original" />
The third step is to initiate time-out whenever the child is noncompliance. Eyberg states that noncompliance will be reinforced by both parental attention and when the child is able to get out of something they do not want to do. An example may be a warning followed by a three-minute time-out.<ref name="Eyberg Original" />
Eventually, as these skills are mastered by the parent, the commands can begin to address relevant behavioral problems the child may be displaying. The approach depends on the treatment goal. For example, if the goal is to increase a certain desired behavior, the parent must break the skill down into simpler parts that can be built on through practice and labeled praise until the child masters it.<ref name="Eyberg Original" />
==Assessments== ===Dyadic Parent-Child Interaction System (DPICS)=== DPICS is an observational system originally created for conduct problem families.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1037/0022-006X.49.2.245 |pmid=7217491 |title=The dyadic parent–child interaction coding system: Standardization and validation |journal=Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology |volume=49 |issue=2 |pages=245–50 |year=1981 |last1=Robinson |first1=Elizabeth A |last2=Eyberg |first2=Sheila M }}</ref> It uses direct observations of behaviors to assess parent-child interactions. DPICS has undergone two revisions since its first edition published in 1981. The DPICS categories serve as indicators of relationship quality, measured by verbal and physical behaviors during social interactions.<ref>Eyberg, S. M., Nelson, M. M., Duke, M., & Boggs, S. R. (2004). Manual for the Dyadic Parent-Child Interaction Coding System Third Edition.{{pn|date=April 2018}}</ref> Examples of parent behavior categories are direct and indirect commands, behavior descriptions, reflective statements, praise, information descriptions, questions, and negative talk. Child behavior categories include compliance and noncompliance, physical positive and negative, yell, whine, smart talk, laugh, and destructive behavior.<ref name="”Herschell”" />
===Eyberg Child Behavior Inventory (ECBI)=== The ECBI is a 36-item behavior scale that is used to track disruptive behaviors in children. It was constructed from data indicating the most typical problem behaviors reported by parents of conduct problem children. The measure includes two scales: Intensity and Problem. Parents report Intensity by rating how frequent each item occurs. The Problem scale asks parents “Is this behavioral problem for you?” to which parents respond “yes” or “no”. This measure can be used for children aged 2 to 16.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1080/15374417809532835 |title=Assessment of child behavior problems: The validation of a new inventory |journal=Journal of Clinical Child Psychology |volume=7 |issue=2 |pages=113 |year=2009 |last1=Eyberg |first1=Sheila M |last2=Ross |first2=Arthur W }}</ref>
==Applications== ===Behavior problems=== Disruptive behavior problems are the leading reason for children's referrals to mental health professionals.<ref name="Ward">{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/s10566-016-9350-5 |title=Parent–Child Interaction Therapy for Child Disruptive Behaviour Disorders: A Meta-analysis |journal=Child & Youth Care Forum |volume=45 |issue=5 |pages=675 |year=2016 |last1=Ward |first1=Michelle A |last2=Theule |first2=Jennifer |last3=Cheung |first3=Kristene }}</ref> and PCIT was first created to target these behaviors.<ref name="Eyberg Original" /> Results from a randomized controlled trial examining the efficacy of PCIT on clinic referred children with diagnoses of [[Oppositional Defiant Disorder]] indicated that compared to the waitlist control group, parents interacted more positively with their children and were more successful at gaining compliance.<ref name="Schuhmann">{{cite journal |doi=10.1207/s15374424jccp2701_4 |pmid=9561935 |title=Efficacy of Parent-Child Interaction Therapy: Interim Report of a Randomized Trial with Short-Term Maintenance |journal=Journal of Clinical Child Psychology |volume=27 |issue=1 |pages=34–45 |year=1998 |last1=Schuhmann |first1=Elena M |last2=Foote |first2=Rebecca C |last3=Eyberg |first3=Sheila M |last4=Boggs |first4=Stephen R |last5=Algina |first5=James }}</ref> Additionally, parents in the treatment group reported decreased parenting stress and more control. Parents also reported significant improvements in their child's behavior following treatment.<ref name="Schuhmann" />
Similar results have been shown in a quasi-experimental study by Boggs and colleagues (2004) that evaluated families who completed the treatment program compared to families who dropped out of the study before completion. For those who completed treatment, parents reported positive changes 10-30 months following treatment in their child's behavior and their parenting stress. Those who dropped out of treatment early did not show significant changes.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1300/J019v26n04_01 |title=Outcomes of Parent-Child Interaction Therapy: A Comparison of Treatment Completers and Study Dropouts One to Three Years Later |journal=Child & Family Behavior Therapy |volume=26 |issue=4 |pages=1 |year=2005 |last1=Boggs |first1=Stephen R |last2=Eyberg |first2=Sheila M |last3=Edwards |first3=Daniel L |last4=Rayfield |first4=Arista |last5=Jacobs |first5=Jenifer |last6=Bagner |first6=Daniel |last7=Hood |first7=Korey K }}</ref>
In a meta-analysis that conducted a comprehensive review of PCIT's efficacy with children diagnosed with ADHD, ODD, or CD, PCIT was found to be an “efficacious intervention for improving externalizing behavior in children with disruptive behavior disorders”.<ref name="Ward" /> Another meta-analysis that focused on parenting stress in addition to child behaviors as outcomes found PCIT to have a “beneficial impact on parents’ and primary caregivers’ perceptions of all outcomes examined, including child externalizing behaviors, child's temperament and self-regulatory abilities, frequency of behavior problems, the difficulty of parent-child interactions, and parent overall distress”.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1080/10522158.2014.888696 |title=Parent–Child Interaction Therapy: A Meta-Analysis of Child Behavior Outcomes and Parent Stress |journal=Journal of Family Social Work |volume=17 |issue=3 |pages=191 |year=2014 |last1=Cooley |first1=Morgan E |last2=Veldorale-Griffin |first2=Amanda |last3=Petren |first3=Raymond E |last4=Mullis |first4=Ann K }}</ref>
The treatment effects of PCIT can also be demonstrated in school settings, despite the treatment program being lab- or home-based.<ref name="Funderburk 2009">{{cite journal |doi=10.1300/J019v20n02_02 |title=Parent-Child Interaction Therapy with Behavior Problem Children: Maintenance of Treatment Effects in the School Setting |journal=Child & Family Behavior Therapy |volume=20 |issue=2 |pages=17 |year=2009 |last1=Funderburk |first1=Beverly W |last2=Eyberg |first2=Sheila M |last3=Newcomb |first3=Katharine |last4=McNeil |first4=Cheryl B |last5=Hembree-Kigin |first5=Toni |last6=Capage |first6=Laura }}</ref> In a study by Funderburk and colleagues (2009), school assessments were administered at 12 months and 18 months following PCIT. At 12 months, results indicated that children in the treatment group maintained their post-treatment improvements, improving within “normal range of conduct problems” compared to the control group. However, though maintaining improvements with compliance, the 18-month followup indicated some declines into the range of levels before treatment.<ref name="Funderburk 2009" />
===Child maltreatment=== Studies have examined the effectiveness of PCIT with families at risk or engaged in [[child maltreatment]]. Evidence suggests that factors such as coercive patterns of parent-child interactions, less sensitivity towards the child, and insecure child attachment can be risks for child maltreatmen.t<ref name="Thomas 2012">{{cite journal |doi=10.1177/1077559512459555 |pmid=22942167 |title=Parent–Child Interaction Therapy |journal=Child Maltreatment |volume=17 |issue=3 |pages=253–66 |year=2012 |last1=Thomas |first1=Rae |last2=Zimmer-Gembeck |first2=Melanie J }}</ref> In a randomized controlled trial composing of 12-session PCIT, mothers reported less internalizing and externalizing behaviors in children in the PCIT group.<ref name="Thomas 2012" /> Additionally, mothers reported less stress, more positive verbalizations and maternal sensitivity.<ref name="Thomas 2011">{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1467-8624.2010.01548.x |pmid=21291436 |title=Accumulating Evidence for Parent-Child Interaction Therapy in the Prevention of Child Maltreatment |journal=Child Development |volume=82 |issue=1 |pages=177–92 |year=2011 |last1=Thomas |first1=Rae |last2=Zimmer-Gembeck |first2=Melanie J }}</ref> Other studies have found similar results, including a reduction of abuse risk post-treatment compared to the waitlist control.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/s10578-011-0226-5 |title=The Effectiveness of Parent–Child Interaction Therapy with Depressive Mothers: The Changing Relationship as the Agent of Individual Change |journal=Child Psychiatry & Human Development |volume=42 |issue=4 |pages=406 |year=2011 |last1=Timmer |first1=Susan G |last2=Ho |first2=Lareina K. L |last3=Urquiza |first3=Anthony J |last4=Zebell |first4=Nancy M |last5=Fernandez y Garcia |first5=Erik |last6=Boys |first6=Deanna }}</ref><ref name="Thomas 2011" />
====Foster care==== PCIT may also be an effective intervention for maltreated children in foster care settings. Because children with behavioral problems in foster care are more likely to have multiple foster care placements and mental health problems, the interventions that improve foster parents’ skills in managing children's difficult behaviors are needed. Findings from a study comparing foster parents and their foster children to non-abusive biological parents and their children demonstrated PCIT's effectiveness in reducing child behavior problems and caregiver distress following treatment for both groups.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.childyouth.2005.01.006 |title=Challenging foster caregiver–maltreated child relationships: The effectiveness of parent–child interaction therapy |journal=Children and Youth Services Review |volume=28 |pages=1 |year=2006 |last1=Timmer |first1=Susan G |last2=Urquiza |first2=Anthony J |last3=Zebell |first3=Nancy }}</ref>
===Depression=== The PCIT has been adapted to treat [[major depressive disorder]] in preschool-aged children, called the PCIT-ED.<ref name="Lenze">{{cite journal |doi=10.1002/da.20770 |pmid=21284068 |pmc=3302425 |title=Parent-child interaction therapy emotion development: A novel treatment for depression in preschool children |journal=Depression and Anxiety |volume=28 |issue=2 |pages=153–9 |year=2011 |last1=Lenze |first1=Shannon N |last2=Pautsch |first2=Jennifer |last3=Luby |first3=Joan }}</ref> The Emotional Development module (ED) was added to target emotion development impairments in very young children, specifically.<ref name="Lenze" /> Its goal is to help children regulate and understand their own emotions more effectively. The two phases of PCIT, CDI and PDI, are retained, but are shortened to six session per phase. Parents are taught skills that help their child in identifying and managing their emotions. For example, this may involve recognizing the child's “triggers” and using relaxation techniques to calm them. Often, parents may try to stop the child's expression of negative emotion, but during ED, parents are taught to tolerate these negative emotions so their child can learn to regulate them.{{fact|date=April 2018}}
The pilot study of the PCIT-ED was an open trial study that examined a group of preschool children with depression, assessing symptoms before and after treatment. This study showed decreased depressive symptoms in children, and most children no longer met [[major depressive disorder]] criteria upon completion of treatment. Additionally, children improved their coping skills, prosocial behaviors, and thought processes.<ref name="Lenze" /> The first randomized controlled trial that compared PCIT-ED to psychoeducation in depressed preschoolers and their caregivers also showed significant improvement two weeks posttreatment for the PCIT-ED group in emotion development, child executive functioning, and parenting stress.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1469-7610.2011.02483.x |pmid=22040016 |pmc=3640820 |title=A novel early intervention for preschool depression: Findings from a pilot randomized controlled trial |journal=Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry |volume=53 |issue=3 |pages=313–22 |year=2012 |last1=Luby |first1=Joan |last2=Lenze |first2=Shannon |last3=Tillman |first3=Rebecca }}</ref>
===Separation anxiety disorder=== [[Separation anxiety disorder]] (SAD) is the most common [[anxiety]] disorder in children which is characterized by an “excessive fear response to real or imagined separation from a caregiver”.<ref name="Pincus">{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.cbpra.2007.08.002 |title=The Implementation of Modified Parent-Child Interaction Therapy for Youth with Separation Anxiety Disorder |journal=Cognitive and Behavioral Practice |volume=15 |issue=2 |pages=118 |year=2008 |last1=Pincus |first1=Donna B |last2=Santucci |first2=Lauren C |last3=Ehrenreich |first3=Jill T |last4=Eyberg |first4=Sheila M }}</ref> PCIT involves many parenting skills that are important in reducing children's anxiety, such as command training, selective attention, reinforcement, and shaping the child's behavior.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S1077-7229(05)80047-1 |title=Parent-child interaction therapy for treatment of separation anxiety disorder in young children: A pilot study |journal=Cognitive and Behavioral Practice |volume=12 |pages=126 |year=2005 |last1=Choate |first1=Molly L |last2=Pincus |first2=Donna B |last3=Eyberg |first3=Sheila M |last4=Barlow |first4=David H }}</ref>
Pilot study results by Pincus and colleagues (2008) evaluating the efficacy of PCIT in 10 young children with SAD showed that did not improve to nonclinical levels posttreatment, however there was improvement in the severity of SAD.<ref name="Pincus" /> Pincus and colleagues (2008) also proposed an adaptation to the PCIT that would include the Bravery-Directed Interaction (BDI) phase.<ref name="Pincus" /> The BDI phase includes a psychoeducational component for the parents about anxiety. It also includes a gradual exposure to the separation situations the child fears. This exposure is key for all anxiety disorders. The BDI focuses on establishing a sense of control in the child by giving them the freedom to choose one exposure activity a week from the “Bravery Ladder” homework assignment, rather than having their parent choose. An initial randomized controlled trial has been conducted to evaluate the modified PCIT, comparing its efficacy to a waitlist control group. It seeks to assess the maintenance of change at 3, 6, and 12 months posttreatment. Preliminary results of study show decreased severity of SAD post-treatment.<ref name="Pincus" />
===Domestic and interparental violence exposure=== Children are at an especially high risk for externalizing and internalizing problems following interparental violence-exposure or [[domestic violence]]. Borrego and colleagues (2008) have provided rationale for the use of PCIT with domestic violence-exposed women and their children, proposing that the parent training component may be very beneficial for mothers who may have “low levels of confidence in their own parenting capabilities and may also have low self-esteem”.<ref name="Borrego">{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/s10896-008-9177-4 |title=Parent–Child Interaction Therapy with Domestic Violence Populations |journal=Journal of Family Violence |volume=23 |issue=6 |pages=495 |year=2008 |last1=Borrego |first1=Joaquin |last2=Gutow |first2=Mindy R |last3=Reicher |first3=Shira |last4=Barker |first4=Chikira H }}</ref> Additionally, Borrego and colleagues (2008) emphasized that because PCIT is relationship-based, it may improve the quality of the mother-child relationship, developing a secure attachment between mother and child, and may lead to a decrease in the severity of trauma symptoms experienced by both.<ref name="Borrego" />
One study by Timmer and colleagues (2010) compared the effectiveness of PCIT in reducing behavior problems in maltreated children exposed to interparental violence (IPV) and similar children with no history of IPV-exposure. Results indicated that there were decreases in behavior problems and caregivers’ distress from pre- to posttreatment in both the IPV-exposed and non-exposed groups. However, there was no significant difference between variations of IPV exposure.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1891/0886-6708.25.4.486 |pmid=20712147 |title=The Effectiveness of Parent–Child Interaction Therapy for Victims of Interparental Violence |journal=Violence and Victims |volume=25 |issue=4 |pages=486–503 |year=2010 |last1=Timmer |first1=Susan G |last2=Ware |first2=Lisa M |last3=Urquiza |first3=Anthony J |last4=Zebell |first4=Nancy M }}</ref>
==Delivery of treatment== ===In-home=== The implementation of PCIT in the home has been examined in order to increase accessibility. Protocol was followed as closely as possible, with the exception that treatment was conducted within the home. Some modifications may be necessary in this setting. For example, the bug-in-ear (a small, wireless earpiece) was used for coaching parents could not be used. Instead, therapists were present in the same room for coaching, typically behind the caregiver, giving discrete feedback.<ref name="Ware">{{cite journal |doi=10.1080/07317100802060302 |title=Efficacy of In-Home Parent-Child Interaction Therapy |journal=Child & Family Behavior Therapy |volume=30 |issue=2 |pages=99 |year=2008 |last1=Ware |first1=Lisa M |last2=McNeil |first2=Cheryl B |last3=Masse |first3=Joshua |last4=Stevens |first4=Sarah }}</ref> Therapists were able to conduct DPICS observations, however these observations were coded live.
The in-home administration of PCIT in a single-subject study by Ware and colleagues (2012) has yielded promising results, such as decrease in caregiver use of negative behavior and increase in use of positive behavior and praise posttreatment.<ref name="Ware" /> PCIT has also shown to improve child outcomes as well. PCIT completers were found to have significantly lower risk of child abuse compared to noncompleters,<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1080/07317107.2012.707079 |title=Effectiveness of Parent–Child Interaction Therapy Delivered to At-Risk Families in the Home Setting |journal=Child & Family Behavior Therapy |volume=34 |issue=3 |pages=177 |year=2012 |last1=Galanter |first1=Rachel |last2=Self-Brown |first2=Shannon |last3=Valente |first3=Jessica R |last4=Dorsey |first4=Shannon |last5=Whitaker |first5=Daniel J |last6=Bertuglia-Haley |first6=Michelle |last7=Prieto |first7=Metta }}</ref> decrease in child behavior problems, and increased child compliance posttreatment.<ref name="Ware" />
There are certain advantages that come with in-home PCIT. For example, therapists are able to take advantage of more authentic, “real life” behaviors that may not be accurately captured within a laboratory or clinic setting. Additionally, in-home PCIT can combat attrition, a problem commonly faced by therapists.<ref name="Masse">{{cite journal |doi=10.1080/07317100802060310 |title=In-Home Parent-Child Interaction Therapy: Clinical Considerations |journal=Child & Family Behavior Therapy |volume=30 |issue=2 |pages=127 |year=2008 |last1=Masse |first1=Joshua J |last2=McNeil |first2=Cheryl B }}</ref>
This approach has potential drawbacks, as well. For example, because homes vary greatly across families, it is much more difficult for therapists control, unlike a laboratory or clinic setting. It may also be more difficult to keep children within the room and within the therapist's sight, as the child has more freedom to “escape” if needed.<ref name="Masse" /> These problems can be avoided by deciding beforehand which room the therapy will take place and by minimizing potential distractions. Availability of resources can be an issue as well, particularly when the treatment requires use of age-appropriate toys that are typically controlled by the therapist in clinical settings. In homes, there may be limited options of activities. However, talking to the parent beforehand about what they might prefer to play with may be helpful, and the therapist can plan to bring the toys needed.<ref name="Masse" />
===Community-based=== PCIT implemented in the community involves administration in community settings such as in the home, mental health services agencies, or family services agencies. Few studies have examined the effectiveness of PCIT in community settings, however one implementation through community agencies has shown decreases in behavior problems, improved parent-child interactions, reduced parental stress in a four-family clinical case study posttreatment.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.cbpra.2010.12.002 |title=Delivering Parent-Child Interaction Therapy in an Urban Community Clinic |journal=Cognitive and Behavioral Practice |volume=18 |issue=4 |pages=502 |year=2011 |last1=Budd |first1=Karen S |last2=Hella |first2=Bryce |last3=Bae |first3=Hyo |last4=Meyerson |first4=David A |last5=Watkin |first5=Sarah C }}</ref> Additionally, a study by Lanier and colleagues (2014) found PCIT to be effective for maltreatment prevention in a group of families receiving PCIT at posttreatment followup.<ref name="Lanier">{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/s10826-012-9708-8 |pmid=24443637 |pmc=3891779 |title=Preventing Maltreatment with a Community-Based Implementation of Parent–Child Interaction Therapy |journal=Journal of Child and Family Studies |volume=23 |issue=2 |pages=449–460 |year=2012 |last1=Lanier |first1=Paul |last2=Kohl |first2=Patricia L |last3=Benz |first3=Joan |last4=Swinger |first4=Dawn |last5=Drake |first5=Brett }}</ref>
===Internet-based=== In an effort to increase accessibility and address obstacles of receiving treatment, especially in underserved communities, an internet-based delivery of PCIT has been proposed and tested. This method uses video conferencing, webcams, and wireless earpieces, allowing for therapists to continue to provide real-time feedback to caregivers, right from the comfort of their home.<ref name="Comer">{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.cbpra.2014.07.003 |pmid=26120268 |pmc=4480784 |title=Rationale and Considerations for the Internet-Based Delivery of Parent–Child Interaction Therapy |journal=Cognitive and Behavioral Practice |volume=22 |issue=3 |pages=302–316 |year=2015 |last1=Comer |first1=Jonathan S |last2=Furr |first2=Jami M |last3=Cooper-Vince |first3=Christine |last4=Madigan |first4=Ryan J |last5=Chow |first5=Candice |last6=Chan |first6=Priscilla T |last7=Idrobo |first7=Fabio |last8=Chase |first8=Rhea M |last9=McNeil |first9=Cheryl B |last10=Eyberg |first10=Sheila M }}</ref> Advantages of this method include the ability to generalize findings better because families were treated in natural settings, which are the settings in which child disruptive behaviors are most likely to manifest.
Availability of resources can pose as a problem when implementing this method of PCIT. Success is dependent on families owning, or being provided, microphones, ear pieces, webcams, computers, and Wi-Fi hotspots. In homes that lack Wi-Fi or have suboptimal internet connections, real-time feedback from therapists may be affected. Treatment providers may be able to provide the necessary equipment for families to borrow, however this depends heavily on the availability of grant funds.<ref name="Comer" />
A randomized trial has been conducted with the Internet-Delivered Parent-Child Interaction Therapy (I-PCIT) and has shown support for its effectiveness in treating children with disruptive behavior disorders. Parents perceived less barriers to treatment when compared to those receiving clinic-based PCIT.<ref name="Comer" /> This study demonstrated decreases in children's symptoms and burden to parents in a randomized clinical trial compared to a waitlist control group, and to traditional in-office PCIT administration.<ref name="Comer" /> Additionally, roughly half of the children in the study no longer met the diagnostic criteria for [[disruptive behavior disorder]].<ref name="Comer" />
==Criticisms== In addition to the time-out component, Eyberg (1988) also recommended swatting child's bottom and other physical punishment as a form of discipline<ref name="Eyberg Original" />, however in a study by Timmer and colleagues (2005), physical punishment was not found to be necessary<ref name="Timmer">{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.chiabu.2005.01.003 |title=Parent-Child Interaction Therapy: Application to maltreating parent-child dyads |journal=Child Abuse & Neglect |volume=29 |issue=7 |pages=825 |year=2005 |last1=Timmer |first1=Susan G |last2=Urquiza |first2=Anthony J |last3=Zebell |first3=Nancy M |last4=McGrath |first4=Jean M }}</ref> and has since been removed from the PCIT protocol. Timmer (2005) further suggested that it did not add anything and suggested a more hands-off approach to parenting.<ref name="Timmer" />
Attrition rates among families receiving PCIT are an ongoing concern.<ref name="Lanier" /> In a meta-analysis by Thomas and Zimmer-Gembeck (2012), attrition rates ranged from 18 to 35% among studies that reported attrition.<ref name="Thomas 2011" />
